<math alttext="The figure presents 3 row table, with 9 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “x.” The heading for row 2 is “f prime of x.” the heading for row 3 is “f double prime of x.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. 0 is less than x, is less than 1. f prime of x is Positive. f double prime of x is Unknown. Column 2. x equals 1. f prime of x is 0. f double prime of x is negative 5. Column 3. 1 is less than x, is less than 2. f prime of x is Negative. f double prime of x is Negative. Column 4. x equals 2. f prime of x does not exist. f double prime of x does not exist. Column 5. 2 is less than x, is less than 3. f prime of x is Positive. f double prime of x is Negative. Column 6. x equals 3. f prime of x is 0. f double prime of x is 0. Column 7. 3 is less than x, is less than 4. f prime of x is Positive. f double prime of x is Positive. Column 8. x equals 4. f prime of x is 0. f double prime of x is 0. Column 9. 4 is less than x, is less than 5. f prime of x is Unknown. f double prime of x is Unknown." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0em" columnwidth="3em 0.05em 5em 3em 5em 3em 5em 3em 5em 3em 5em" equalrows="false" frame="solid" framespacing="0em 0ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="0.05em" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>x</mi></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>1</mn></mtd><mtd><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>1</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>2</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn><mo><</mo><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mn>5</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd></mtd><mtd></mtd><mtd></mtd><mtd></mtd><mtd></mtd><mtd></mtd><mtd></mtd><mtd></mtd><mtd></mtd><mtd></mtd><mtd></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Negative</mtext></mtd><mtd><mrow><mtext>DNE</mtext></mrow></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mtext>Unknown</mtext></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>″</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mtext>Unknown</mtext></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mtext>Negative</mtext></mtd><mtd><mtext>DNE</mtext></mtd><mtd><mtext>Negative</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Positive</mtext></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mtext>Unknown</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>
The function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is continuous on the interval <math alttext="open parenthesis, 0 comma 5, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and is twice differentiable except at <math alttext="x equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, where the derivatives do not exist (DNE). Information about the first and second derivatives of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for some values of <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in the interval <math alttext="open parenthesis, 0 comma 5, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is given in the table above. Which of the following statements could be false?

choices.label: The function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has a relative maximum at <math alttext="x equals 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has a relative minimum at <math alttext="x equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The graph of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has a point of inflection at <math alttext="x equals 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The graph of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has a point of inflection at <math alttext="x equals 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: The graph of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> has a point of inflection at <math alttext="x equals 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 5.8: Sketching Graphs of Functions and Their Derivatives

skill.text: Skill 2.D: Identify how mathematical characteristics or properties of functions are related in different representations.
